title: Worked Solution
text:
To find the equation of a line with slope $$m$$ and passing through a point (x1, y1), we use the point-slope form:

$$y$$ - y1 $$=$$ m(x - x1)

In this problem, $$m$$ $$=$$ $$-6$$ and the point (x1, y1) $$=$$ (1/4, -2). Substituting these values into the point-slope form, we get:

$$y$$ - $$(-2)$$ $$=$$ -6(x - 1/4)

Simplifying the right side, we get:

$$y$$ + $$2$$ $$=$$ $$-6x$$ + $$ rac{3}{2}$$

Subtracting $$2$$ from both sides, we get:

$$y$$ $$=$$ $$-6x$$ - $$ rac{1}{2}$$

To write the equation in standard form (Ax + By $$=$$ C), we need to move all the variables to one side of the equation:

$$6x$$ + $$y$$ $$=$$ $$ rac{-1}{2}$$

Multiplying both sides by $$-2$$ to get rid of the fraction, we get:

$$-12x$$ - $$2y$$ $$=$$ $$1$$

So the equation of the line with slope $$m$$ $$=$$ $$-6$$ and passing through the point (1/4, -2) is:

$$-12x$$ - $$2y$$ $$=$$ $$1$$.
